section.title: Roundtripping XLIFF <cp/>
section.para: XLIFF <cp> represents a Unicode character that is invalid in XML.

simplelist.member: JLIFF doesn't have an equivalent to XLIFF <cp>

section.para: Equivalent of the above example in JLIFF:
section.programlisting:
WIP
^C [Oxyegn doesn't accept the literal even in CDATA] \u "Ctrl+C=\u0003"
section.para: The example above shows a character U+0003 (Control C) as it has to be represented in XLIFF. As the character ETX is legal in JSON, the <cp hex="0003"> becomes the literal of "^C" or "ETX" in the JLIFF serialization. in case of mixed XLIFF and JLIFF pipelines the conversion mechanism needs to be able to "cp-encode" XML illegal characters in LIFF on the fly or vice versa to replace the "cp-encoded" XLIFF representations with their literal equivalents in JLIFF.

listitem.para: JLIFF Writers receiving XLIFF <cp> must replace the code with the corresponding literal character given by the XLIFF hex attribute.

XLIFF Writers receiving illegal XML characters (Unicode characters with hexadecimal codes from 0000 to 10FFFF) must replace each XML illegal character with the XLIFF <cp> element using the corresponding hex attribute.
XLIFF Writers must not encode valid XML characters of the content using <cp>.
